Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2009 10:14AM ejlj wrote: Our bodies really take a beating from all the chemo drugs. my elbow was KILLING me soon after I finished chemo.  I was totally freaked.  the onc said he wasn't worried, then a bump appeared which freaked me out even more.  of course I ran back to onc and he still said he wasn't worried.  My husband is a surgeon and he and I both think it's a ganglion.  I am now on Celebrex 2x/day and my aches and pains have finally improved.  Have you tried any anti-inflammatories?  Tina

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 09:16AM ejlj wrote: Anitach  I'm sorry to hear of the stress you are going through.  I too have been worried about my neck and am trying to put it out of my mind.  Although I can't feel anything and haven't mentioned it to my oncologist, I have been having persistant discomfort along the right side of my neck as well as shooting pains in and around my forhead for a few days now.   I also have been having moments of forgetfulness and just plain being weird.  I laugh at the things that I do, but can't help think of metastatic disease.   Your posting also caught my eye, as we are about the same age and from your photo it looks as though you have small children.  I have four.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 01:12PM ejlj wrote: FloridaLady-Congrats on your meltaways! and thanks for the helpful information as well as Nichola. Anitach-Thanks too.  I'll definately check out that information on Herceptin and Headaches.  Fyi-my kids are 12, 10, 8, and 4.  All very close to your kids age.  Infact they accompanied me to radiation today as there was no school due to weather.  How sad is it that our kids have to be affected by this terrible disease?!?!  My treatment thus far has been-Hercepin & Taxol x 12 doses 1x/wk starting about 10 days after dx, followed by mastectomy and lymphnode disection with a tissue expander placed, AC x 4 doses (finished beginning of October), radiation X 26 doses ( I finish tomorrow!) and have recently restarted Herceptin again and have had 3 doses so far.  Please keep me (us) uptodate on your PET scan results.  I wish you the best and wil keep you in my prayers.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 06:13PM ejlj wrote: it's always a real shocker to get that final path report when you expected it to be different.  Like you, I had neoadjuvant chemo of taxol/herceptin x 12 doses.  at my presurgical mri, it showed no evidence of disease, but path report stated differently.  still had tumor and positive nodes.  that part really sucked, but the good part was that the tumor looked like "swiss cheese" and I had much fewer positive nodes than showed up on initial scans!  I then went on to A/C x 4, radiation and more herceptin.  Don't get too discourage.  I know it's not the BEST news but you still have more treatment to go and that will definately help you in the long run!  tina

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 07:49PM ejlj wrote: bev, did you have any response to the chemo?  I couldn't tell from your entry.  I too had neo chemo and thougth I had a complete response from preop mri until path cam back with residual tumor and + nodes.  I know it's a total bummer!  But for me and I'm hoping it's the same for you-I KNOW I would of had way more nodes positive and even though the tumor was still there, it was definately hurting!  the md said the report stated it looked like swiss cheese even thought the overall size hadn't changed by much.  Ask about the tumor, you may of had more of a response than you think.  I also had chemo after surgery which helped give me confidence that we kicked the cancers $%^ one last time!  Tina

Posts.Title: Markers up - Taxotere treatment. Mabledw luvtotravel

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 09:33PM ejlj wrote: hi mable,  sorry your feeling so crummy.  You could have a fever for alot of reasons.  Your body is going through a lot right now.  If it's low grade, it may just be due to stress and dehydration.  If it's closer to the 101 mark, I'd be more concerned with infection.  Did they draw blood cultures is the hospital?  Your port could also be another souce.  Keep on top of it and let us know how you do.  Tina
Posts.Title: Markers up - Taxotere treatment. Mabledw luvtotravel

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2008 09:45AM ejlj wrote: Hi sherry, I got a seroma many weeks after my surgery as well as an infection and needed iv antibiotics.  I had to have it drained several times and then it finally resolved.  I did have some fluid that drained from it as well.  I would definately call your surgeon and have it checked out especially before the holiday.  If you just have a seroma, it doesn't mean that you have an infection.  I just happened to have both-lucky I guess! LOL  Tina

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 08:10PM ejlj wrote: i had a base line bone density and it was in the normal range.  i'm not on any antiestrogens as i am her-2 neu+ and my insurance company payed for the drug.  I'm not sure of the cost out of pocket, but if it's that important to you, maybe that's an option???  I too am terrified of the jaw necrosis.  I know it's rare, but don't want one more thing to worry about.  but when i think about it, my chances for metastatic bone disease is probley greater than jaw necrosis.  I also THINK that it is a greater risk with the IV biophospahnates than the oral.  thanks for all your input.  Tina

Posts.Title: Breast cancer signs, symptoms and risk factors

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 08:59PM ejlj wrote: sorry this has been so traumatic for you.  I know being 22 and having to deal with body image is a very big deal and I do not mean to minimize that, however, I tend to think your surgeon may have done an ok job.  I truely think he had your best interest (and your life)in mind when he took the wide excision.  Please keep in mind mammogram/us/mri's only show a small picture of what actually is in your breast.  I had testing prior to my mastectomy that showed NO EVIDENCE OF DISEASE but still had a tumor left, quite large at the time of surgery!  Cancer or not, I wanted it out!  I'm sure things were not as they looked on scans once he openned you out.  What if he left it in and it ended up being cancer, now that would be neglegent!  As for the bruising below the area you were operated on, blood will pool internally to the most dependant areas, meaning it's not uncommon to see bruising LOWER than where you would expect to see it.  I hope this helps.  I know your angery.  this whole process really sucks, but please keep in mind how wonderful it is to know you are cancer free!!!!!  Tina
Posts.Title: Did my doctor butcher me/screw up? FREAKING OUT! sueelizabeth676 sueelizabeth676
